items.title: Rome wasn't rewritten in a day
items.content:
#‚Äã614 ‚Äî November 11, 2022

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Rome v10: Rust-Powered JS Linting and Formatting ‚Äî A project founded by the original creator of Babel naturally provokes interest. Rome‚Äôs ambitious mission is to unify all the frontend dev tools you‚Äôd need into one, and formatting and linting is where they‚Äôve started with this curiously numbered release. Shouldn't it should be Rome¬†X?¬†üòÅ

The Rome Team

Editorial note: "Oh no, another tool!" I hear you cry. Despite its youth, Rome already has some compelling points in its favor, including rich diagnostics that not only drill into what is wrong with your code, but why it's wrong. It will be fantastic to see this sort of tooling advance further.

A Complete TypeScript Learning Path ‚Äî Many teams are introducing types to their Web and Node.js apps with TypeScript. Over four courses going from the fundamentals through to production, let Mike North bring you up to speed with TypeScript's power and capabilities for writing more robust¬†code.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Why Would Anyone Need Generator Functions? ‚Äî You can go a long time without feeling the need for generators. So, you may wonder, what are they good for? While they may not be essential, they do have utility and can change how you approach certain problems. James cracks out the chocolate biscuits to¬†explain.

James Sinclair

Gatsby 5.0: The Fastest Gatsby Yet ‚Äî The performance oriented React-based framework (that isn‚Äôt Next.js) takes a leap forward with the Slice API for speeding up common updates across a site, partial hydration (beta), a new Script component for loading scripts, incremental builds and deploys, and more. This release follows Gatsby‚Äôs fresh pitch as a ‚Äòreactive site¬†generator‚Äô.

Josh Johnson (Gatsby Team)

IN BRIEF:

  • Get ready to spruce up your READMEs with GitHub Blocks: dynamic components you'll be able to add to your README to include demos, live stats, search features, comparison tables, etc.

  • Overwhelmed by the constant influx of new frameworks? It's a good thing, concluded a panel of framework creators at Jamstack Conf this week.

  • The results from Vercel's Netlify's (thanks to Cassidy Williams for the correction!) Jamstack Community Survey 2022 are out. Serverless, React, and Next.js all saw huge popularity. (‚Üí Via JAMstacked)

  • A look at the state of IPFS in relation to JavaScript. (IPFS is a large distributed peer-to-peer storage system and protocol.)

RELEASES:

  • Parcel 2.8
    ‚Ü≥ Zero-config build tool. Quite a big release with a brand new bundling algorithm and improved automatic code splitting.

  • Node.js 19.0.1, 18.12.1, 16.18.1 and 14.21.1

  • Hapi 21 ‚Äì 'Batteries included' Node framework.

  • pnpm 7.15 ‚Äì Fast, space efficient package manager.

üìÖ¬†Register for Unblock 2022 - A CI/CD Conference by Buildkite

Buildkite sponsor

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

The Temporal API: JavaScript Dates, but Better ‚Äî Working with dates in JavaScript is clunky enough for there to be a whole ecosystem of libraries to make it easier (e.g. Moment.js) but Temporal is a (stage 3) proposal to bring a modern date/time API into¬†play.

Vlad Mihet

Creating 'Fluffy Trees' with Three.js ‚Äî If you want to make something very pretty with JavaScript and GLSL shaders this¬†weekend.

Michael Dougall

Node.js Security Best Practices ‚Äî A new official document from the Node.js team providing guidelines on securing your Node apps by looking at what the main threats are and how to mitigate¬†them.

Node.js Project

‚ñ∂¬†¬†A Podcast for Candid Chats on Product, Business & Leadership ‚Äî Join Postlight leaders & guests as they discuss topics like running great meetings & creating solid product¬†launches.

The Postlight Podcast sponsorpodcast

Migrating from Monaco Editor to CodeMirror ‚Äî The folks at Sourcegraph share what they gained in switching their in-browser code editor to what could arguably be considered a less modern¬†option.

Kling and Dorfman

A Love Letter to React (from the Creator of¬†Phoenix) ‚Äî A warm-hearted enumeration of React‚Äôs positive qualities from the folks at Fly.io. An interesting angle is the author is the creator of Elixir‚Äôs Phoenix framework which itself borrows ideas from¬†React.

Chris McCord (Fly.io)

How to Dedupe 28 Million Strings with JavaScript? ‚Äî Fun question (and answers) on Stack Overflow. This task isn‚Äôt exactly a great fit for either JavaScript or its runtimes, but there‚Äôs always a¬†way.

Stack Overflow

‚ö†Ô∏è¬†‚ñ∂Ô∏è A Next.js 13 Warning: An Easy Infinite Loop Mistake ‚Äî Jack explains this¬†well.
Jack Herrington

Using TypeScript with Node.js
Robin Wieruch

Using Web Components with Next (or Any SSR Framework)
Adam Rackis

Exploring Bun‚Äôs Built-In React Boilerplate
Mayank Choubey

Mocking a Class with Jest: Two Ways to Make It Easier
Geshan Manandhar

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

Trix 2.0: A Rich WYSIWYG Editor for the Web ‚Äî A WYSIWYG editor developed by the folks at 37signals (known as the birthplace of Ruby on Rails). It‚Äôs used in Basecamp so is about as stress tested as you can get. GitHub¬†repo.

Basecamp

Riot.js 7.1: A Simple and Elegant Component-Based UI Library ‚Äî An interesting alternative UI library that might click with you. It‚Äôs designed to offer you ‚Äúeverything you wished" the native web components API looked like. GitHub¬†repo.

Riot.js

Integrate a Scheduling Widget to Your App in Less Than a Day ‚Äî Extensive API offering a high level of customization. Seamless integration into React, Angular, Vue, or vanilla JS¬†apps.

Bryntum sponsor

React Calendar 4.0: The 'Ultimate' Calendar for Your React App ‚Äî A popular, simple-styled calendar component for React apps, focused mostly on letting users pick dates. Note that you‚Äôll need to be on React 16.8+ to use v4.0 though. GitHub¬†repo.

Wojciech Maj

safe-json-value 1.9: For When JSON Serialization Should Never Fail ‚Äî Prevents JSON.serialize() from throwing an exeception, changing types, or otherwise transforming values unexpectedly, because sometimes you need that sort of¬†reassurance.

ehmicky

Rockpack 3.0: An Alternative React App¬†Builder ‚Äî Like Create React App Rockpack's goal is to keep project setup time low, but it holds some different opinions around how far to go and packs in many ideas like server side rendering and, now, linting.

Alex Sergey

  • WaveSurfer.js 6.4
    ‚Ü≥ Navigable waveforms atop Web Audio & Canvas.¬†(Demos.)

  • Kosko 3.0
    ‚Ü≥ Organize Kubernetes manifests in JavaScript.

  • Marked 4.2.2
    ‚Ü≥ Perf-focused Markdown parser and compiler.¬†(Demo.)

  • React Bootstrap 2.6 ‚Äî Bootstrap 5 components for React.

  • React Tooltip 4.5 ‚Äì A tooltip component, surprisingly.¬†(Demo.)

  • Strapi 4.5 ‚Äì Popular Node-based headless CMS.

  • Nest.js 9.2 ‚Äì Server-side Node.js framework.

üíª Jobs

UX Engineer ‚Äî Stimulus is a social platform started by Sticker Mule to show what's possible if your mission is to increase human happiness. Join our engineering¬†team.
Stimulus

Senior JavaScript/TypeScript Developer (Remote or Warsaw) üáµüá± ‚Äî Take the next step in your career and help us migrate CKEditor 5 to TypeScript! Develop the software used by millions of users¬†üåé
CKEDITOR

Senior Frontend Engineer (San Francisco) ‚Äî Build interfaces for an AI-powered research assistant that makes knowledge workers smarter. TypeScript, React,¬†GraphQL.
Heyday

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
Hired

items.title: Is Turbopack really 10x faster than Vite?
items.content:
#‚Äã613 ‚Äî November 4, 2022

Read on the Web
Together with¬†

JavaScript Weekly

What Is a 'Realm' in JavaScript? ‚Äî One of those things you don‚Äôt need to know, but that will flesh out your understanding of JS under the hood. A realm is essentially the complete execution environment for a JavaScript¬†program.

Gal Weizman

Then if you really want to go down the rabbit hole, enter the ShadowRealm with Dr.¬†Axel..

Is Turbopack Really 10x Faster Than Vite? ‚Äî Last week‚Äôs big news was the unveiling of Turbopack, a Rust-based ‚Äòsuccessor‚Äô to Webpack that boasts significantly performance improvements. Vue and Vite‚Äôs Evan You decided to run some benchmarks and ended up pretty deep down the rabbit¬†hole.

Evan You

Open-Source Firebase Alternative for Web, Mobile & Flutter Devs ‚Äî Appwrite is a secure, self-hosted solution that provides developers with a set of easy-to-use REST APIs to manage their core backend needs. You can build anything with Appwrite! Click here to learn¬†more.

Appwrite sponsor

Shopify Acquires the Remix Project ‚Äî A mere year after being open sourced, Remix, an exciting full stack Web framework and its associated company, has been acquired by e-commerce giant Shopify. Dion (truly a huge name in the JS space in the day) explains why here, but if you‚Äôd prefer a ‚ñ∂Ô∏è snappy two-minute overview then Fireship has you¬†covered.

Dion Almaer (Shopify)

Announcing TypeScript 4.9 RC ‚Äî A long awaited release gets a big step closer. satisfies is introduced to validate that the type of an expression matches some type without changing the actual resulting type. There are also auto-accessors in classes (an upcoming feature in ES itself) and editor enhancements such as ‚ÄúRemove Unused Imports‚Äù and ‚ÄúSort Imports‚Äù. 4.9 final is expected in two¬†weeks.

Daniel Rosenwasser

IN BRIEF:

  • React Native has switched its default new app template from using Flow to¬†TypeScript.

  • üéÑ A group of Vue developers are running ‚úâÔ∏è¬†Advent of Vue, an email-delivered set of festively-themed coding puzzles built around building Vue components. Think Advent of Code but more Vue-y!

  • Key security releases of Node.js are expected imminently (later today!)

  • The Component Gallery is a handy index of components.

  • The Svelte team shares an update on the state of Svelte as of November 2022.

RELEASES:

  • Redux Toolkit 1.9 ‚Äì Official toolset for Redux.

  • Foal 3.0
    ‚Ü≥ Full-featured Node.js webapp framework.

  • Vuetify 3.0
    ‚Ü≥ Material component framework for Vue.

  • Ember 4.8.1, 4.4.4, 3.28.10 & 3.24.7
    ‚Ü≥ Security releases of the framework.

  • VS Code ‚Äì October 2022 edition

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

How to Build, Test, and Publish a TypeScript npm Package in 2022 ‚Äî The bare basic steps in a short and sweet¬†walkthrough.

Ianis Triandafilov

'Your Next.js Bundle Will Thank You' ‚Äî If your Next.js app bundle sizes are bigger than you‚Äôd like, Renato‚Äôs advice is for¬†you.

Renato Pozzi

Creating Human-Readable Date/Time Differences ‚Äî There are libraries to get your ‚Äú2 minutes ago‚Äù, ‚Äú5 months ago‚Äù or ‚Äú1 year ago‚Äù but did you know the Intl API can do it too? Intl.RelativeTimeFormat() is there and supports numerous¬†languages. GitHub's relative-time is an alternative if you need a little¬†extra.

Amit Merchant

Build a Mobile-Responsive Telehealth Pager App Using Stream‚Äôs Chat¬†API ‚Äî Build a responsive chat app with emojis/reactions, built-in GIF support, ability to edit/delete messages, direct & group chat, and¬†more.

Stream sponsor

Code Coverage with Storybook Test Runner ‚Äî Coverage reports can show you how much of your code is actually reached in testing and help you find untested areas. Storybook's test runner now generates coverage reports to help with this and supports React, Preact, Svelte and Vue out of the¬†box.

Yann Braga (Storybook)

How to Package and Distribute a Vue.js 3 Plugin on npm ‚Äî Uses Vite to build things and vue-tsc to generate types for optimal¬†DX.

Daniel Kelly

Building an Accessible Tooltip Component ‚Äî A well structured overview of how to build a color-adaptive and accessible <tool-tip> custom element. There‚Äôs a ‚ñ∂Ô∏è video version of this post if you‚Äôd prefer too. The JavaScript is¬†minimal.

Adam Argyle

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Creating a Minecraft Clone with React and Three.js ‚Äî (91¬†minutes.)
Daniel Berk

Running JavaScript in WebAssembly with WasmEdge ‚Äî Why? Why¬†not!
Second State

An Overview of JavaScript Promises
Sandeep Panda & James Hibbard beginner

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

Vuestic UI 1.5: A UI Library for Vue¬†3 ‚Äî A library of sixty customizable components. v1.5 is a big release boasting significantly improved accessibility, new tree, split view, dropdown and virtual scroll components, dark theming, and more. Official¬†homepage.

Epicmax

Joi 17.7: Object Schema and Data¬†Validations ‚Äî Describe your data using a simple, fluent API and Joi can check if data you supply to it is up to scratch, e.g. Joi.string().min(3).max(30)

Sideway Inc.

Radar SDKs and APIs: Fastest Way to a Wide-Range of Location-Based Experiences ‚Äî Flexible and affordable geocoding, search, and distance APIs with high-quality address and place data. Sign up¬†today.

Radar sponsor

directory-serve: Serve a Local Directory Over HTTP, Quickly ‚Äî This is neat. If you have Node and npm installed, run npx directory-serve . to get an HTTP server serving up the current¬†directory.

Cube-Root

relative-time: An Element to Format a Timestamp as a Localized Relative¬†Time ‚Äî Supply this web component with a standard formatted date and time and it‚Äôll render the right text to¬†suit.

GitHub

Pinceau: A CSS-in-TypeScript Framework Built for Vue ‚Äî Still early days but has the perk of seamless integration into Vue, and works with Nuxt, Vitesse, and Vite.

Ya√´l Guilloux

Markdoc 0.2: A Flexible, Markdown-Based Authoring¬†Framework ‚Äî An extension of Markdown but with extra features ideal for blog posts or docs. It‚Äôs used for Stripe‚Äôs public docs, but you can bring it into your own systems. GitHub¬†repo.

Stripe

Shortcut Brings Product and Engineering Together. Try It for Free

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

  • jest-image-snapshot 6.0
    ‚Ü≥ Matcher for visual comparisons/regressions.

  • Sigma.js 2.4
    ‚Ü≥ High-perf rendering of complex graphs.

  • Docusaurus 2.2
    ‚Ü≥ Facebook's documentation web site builder.

  • Taxi 1.2
    ‚Ü≥ Small library for PJAX navigation and animations to sites.

  • Jasmine 4.5 ‚Äì Testing framework for browsers & Node.

  • Chartist.js 1.3 ‚Äì Simple responsive charts. Not the 1800s political movement.

  • Forge 6.0 ‚Äì Tool to build/publish Electron apps.

  • React Toastify 9.1 ‚Äì On-screen notifications made easy.

  • vanilla-tilt.js 1.7.3 ‚Äì Smooth 3D tilting.

üíª Jobs

Senior JavaScript/TypeScript Developer (Remote or Warsaw) ‚Äî CKEditor is migrating to TypeScript, will you migrate your talent to the CKEditor team? üß≥ Join us and realize your true¬†potential.
CKEditor

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
Hired

üìó¬†We're also reading..

We've also had some tabs open that aren't JavaScript specific but you might find interesting anyway:

Comparing TCP and QUIC by Geoff Huston. If HTTP/3, QUIC and UDP are buzzwords for you and you want to know what's going on under the hood, this is a good technical primer (HTTP/3 is basically HTTP mapped on top of QUIC, as opposed to HTTP 1 and HTTP/2 which use TCP).

Advice That Actually Worked For Me by Nabeel Qureshi. A bit more thoughtful and universal than most advice posts.

A Visual Studio 6.0 Nostalgia Trip by Wouter Groeneveld. I might be showing my age by enjoying this. Next stop.. Delphi! Or QBasic..?

Intl.RelativeTimeFormat() is there and supports numerous¬†languages. GitHub's relative-time is an alternative if you need a little¬†extra.

Build a Mobile-Responsive Telehealth Pager App Using Stream‚Äôs Chat¬†API ‚Äî Build a responsive chat app with emojis/reactions, built-in GIF support, ability to edit/delete messages, direct & group chat, and¬†more.
Stream sponsor


  
  
Code Coverage with Storybook Test Runner ‚Äî Coverage reports can show you how much of your code is actually reached in testing and help you find untested areas. Storybook's test runner now generates coverage reports to help with this and supports React, Preact, Svelte and Vue out of the¬†box.
Yann Braga (Storybook) 


  
  
How to Package and Distribute a Vue.js 3 Plugin on npm ‚Äî Uses Vite to build things and vue-tsc to generate types for optimal¬†DX.
Daniel Kelly 


  
  
Building an Accessible Tooltip Component ‚Äî A well structured overview of how to build a color-adaptive and accessible <tool-tip> custom element. There‚Äôs a ‚ñ∂Ô∏è video version of this post if you‚Äôd prefer too. The JavaScript is¬†minimal.
Adam Argyle 


  
‚ñ∂¬†¬†Creating a Minecraft Clone with React and Three.js ‚Äî (91¬†minutes.)
  
Daniel Berk 
  


  
Running JavaScript in WebAssembly with WasmEdge ‚Äî Why? Why¬†not!
  
Second State 
  


  
An Overview of JavaScript Promises
  
Sandeep Panda & James Hibbard beginner
  


üõ†¬†Code & Tools




  





  
  
Vuestic UI 1.5: A UI Library for Vue¬†3 ‚Äî A library of sixty customizable components. v1.5 is a big release boasting significantly improved accessibility, new tree, split view, dropdown and virtual scroll components, dark theming, and more. Official¬†homepage.
Epicmax 


  
  
Joi 17.7: Object Schema and Data¬†Validations ‚Äî Describe your data using a simple, fluent API and Joi can check if data you supply to it is up to scratch, e.g. Joi.string().min(3).max(30)
Sideway Inc. 


  
  
Radar SDKs and APIs: Fastest Way to a Wide-Range of Location-Based Experiences ‚Äî Flexible and affordable geocoding, search, and distance APIs with high-quality address and place data. Sign up¬†today.
Radar sponsor


  
  
directory-serve: Serve a Local Directory Over HTTP, Quickly ‚Äî This is neat. If you have Node and npm installed, run npx directory-serve . to get an HTTP server serving up the current¬†directory.
Cube-Root 


  
  
relative-time: An Element to Format a Timestamp as a Localized Relative¬†Time ‚Äî Supply this web component with a standard formatted date and time and it‚Äôll render the right text to¬†suit.
GitHub 


  
  
Pinceau: A CSS-in-TypeScript Framework Built for Vue ‚Äî Still early days but has the perk of seamless integration into Vue, and works with Nuxt, Vitesse, and Vite.
Ya√´l Guilloux 


  
  
Markdoc 0.2: A Flexible, Markdown-Based Authoring¬†Framework ‚Äî An extension of Markdown but with extra features ideal for blog posts or docs. It‚Äôs used for Stripe‚Äôs public docs, but you can bring it into your own systems. GitHub¬†repo.
Stripe 


  
  
Shortcut Brings Product and Engineering Together. Try It for Free
Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor




jest-image-snapshot 6.0
Sigma.js 2.4
Docusaurus 2.2
Taxi 1.2
Jasmine 4.5 ‚Äì Testing framework for browsers & Node.
Chartist.js 1.3 ‚Äì Simple responsive charts. Not the 1800s political movement.
Forge 6.0 ‚Äì Tool to build/publish Electron apps.
React Toastify 9.1 ‚Äì On-screen notifications made easy.
vanilla-tilt.js 1.7.3 ‚Äì Smooth 3D tilting.








üíª Jobs





  
Senior JavaScript/TypeScript Developer (Remote or Warsaw) ‚Äî CKEditor is migrating to TypeScript, will you migrate your talent to the CKEditor team? üß≥ Join us and realize your true¬†potential.
  
CKEditor 
  


  
Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
  
Hired 
  










üìó¬†We're also reading..




We've also had some tabs open that aren't JavaScript specific but you might find interesting anyway:
Comparing TCP and QUIC by Geoff Huston. If HTTP/3, QUIC and UDP are buzzwords for you and you want to know what's going on under the hood, this is a  good technical primer (HTTP/3 is basically HTTP mapped on top of QUIC, as opposed to HTTP 1 and HTTP/2 which use TCP).
Advice That Actually Worked For Me by
Nabeel Qureshi. A bit more thoughtful and universal than most advice posts.
A Visual Studio 6.0 Nostalgia Trip by Wouter Groeneveld. I might be showing my age by enjoying this. Next stop.. Delphi! Or QBasic..?

items.title: Turbo-charged incremental bundling au Rust
items.content:
#‚Äã612 ‚Äî October 28, 2022

Read on the Web
Together with¬†

JavaScript Weekly

Turbopack: A Rust-Based 'Successor' to Webpack ‚Äî With over 3 billion downloads, webpack is currently the undisputed champion of the bundlers (though Vite has been rapidly advancing upon it). Vercel found it too slow so has funded work on Turbopack, powered by Rust (a synonym for ‚Äòfaster‚Äô in some circles nowadays.. üòè) It's a project to keep an eye on (especially if you're a Next.js user) and boasts significant performance boosts over webpack and even Vite, but there are some limitations to take into account:

  • It's arguable if it's a "successor" to webpack, as Turbopack can't do much of what Webpack can yet, and while they share a creator, webpack is an active project with maintainers of its own.
  • It's very connected to React and Next.js 13 (also released this week ‚Äì more on that next) ‚Äì Vue and Svelte support is to follow.
  • The similarly Rust-powered SWC is used to transpile JS/TS.
  • Vite's Evan You üê¶ casts some doubt on the perf difference¬†claims. He also has üê¶ a thread with his thoughts on Turbopack¬†generally.
  • In short, unless you are living on the Next.js edge, stick with webpack or Vite for now.

Koppers and Palmer (Vercel)

Implement JavaScript Developer Solutions for Every Project ‚Äî Get dependency-free, fast, flexible, true JavaScript components that enable you to build basic websites, full enterprise applications, Excel-like spreadsheet tools, and reports for your organization. Empower your JavaScript developers¬†today.

GrapeCity sponsor

Node 18 Becomes Active LTS with v18.12.0 ‚Äî Formerly a ‚Äòcurrent‚Äô release getting all the newest features, version 18 is now the active ‚ÄòLong Term Support‚Äô release and will remain so until October 2023. Its codename is Hydrogen ‚Äì quite fitting as the most abundant element in the¬†universe.

Ruy Adorno and Rafael Gonzaga

If you're using an older LTS version and are wondering what Node 18 has to offer, Marian Villa presents 11 Features in Node.js 18 you need to try, including the fetch API, --watch, and the native Node test runner.

IN BRIEF:

  • The SQLite project now has official WASM/JS documentation relating to SQLite's presence in WebAssembly and browser contexts. sql.js has long been the go-to project in this space, but things are heating up.

  • CodePen is a perfect place to play with Preact (the smaller alternative to React) ‚Äì and Chris Coyier explains how.

  • Christian Heilmann reminds us that JSON.stringify can create nicely formatted, filtered, multi-line output strings.

Next.js 13 Unveiled at Next.js Conf ‚Äî Next.js Conf 22 took place earlier this week and as well as Turborepo (above), Vercel unveiled the latest version of the site framework that has become 'inextricably linked' to React. It gains:

  • Support for an app/ directory to improve routing, layouts, and Server Components support ‚Äì can coexist with existing approaches.
  • A new image component with on-demand optimization and the ability to display images without layout shift.
  • A brand new font system.

Vercel

"Next.js is the framework for the web the way k8s is the framework for infrastructure" ‚Äì Kelsey Hightower at Next.js Conf.

JetBrains JavaScript Day 2022: An Event You Won‚Äôt Want to¬†Miss ‚Äî Join JetBrains JavaScript Day 2022 to catch up on the latest trends and connect with other like-minded¬†professionals.

JetBrains sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Babel 7.20.0
    ‚Ü≥ The popular transpiler now supports TypeScript 4.9 and Deno as a compilation target.

  • Handsontable 12.2 ‚Äì Popular spreadsheet-y data grid.

  • Deno 1.27 ‚Äì JS server-side runtime that isn't Node. (Or Bun.)

  • Qwik 0.12 ‚Äì HTML-first framework.

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

Which Serverless Edge Platform Has the Fastest Git Deployments? ‚Äî The team behind Deno have tested some popular serverless edge computing providers (including their own Deno Deploy) to see which has the fastest git deployment¬†time. As always with benchmarks, read the results with a cynical eye and repeat for¬†yourself.

Andy Jiang (Deno)

How We Improved React Loading Times by 70% with Next.js ‚Äî By replacing Create React App with Next.js, business planning platform Causal significantly improved their user experience by reducing load times. How? Well, just a little SSR can get you a long¬†way.

Causal Engineers

How to Build a Blog with Fresh and Deno ‚Äî In other Deno news, if you‚Äôve felt like giving Deno a go for something but been unsure as to what, how about spinning up a simple blog atop the Fresh Web framework? Then deploy it really quickly to Deno Deploy ;-)

Andy Jiang (Deno)

The Fastest Way to Learn JavaScript / TypeScript ‚Äî With 2M+ downloads world-wide, Quokka.js is the #1 tool for exploring and testing JavaScript/TypeScript without leaving your¬†editor.

Wallaby.js sponsor

How to Write Your First Unit Test in JavaScript ‚Äî If you‚Äôre a prolific tester, scroll on. If not, this is a very light¬†primer.

Chip Verek

‚ñ∂¬†¬†A Next.js Crash Course ‚Äî There are a lot of such videos, but this is a well recorded and up to date one so it might help you get the lay of the Next.js land (which seems to be all the rage this week in particular) if you‚Äôre just starting out with it. (2 hours 30¬†minutes)

Anson Foong

Detect a System Theme Preference Change from JS ‚Äî window.matchMedia and addEventListener to the¬†rescue.

David Walsh

Advancements in Angular 14.2's Router
Andrew Scott

Using Cloudinary's Image APIs from Alpine.js
Raymond Camden

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

npoint: Simple JSON Storage Bins with Schema Validation ‚Äî You can use this as a lightweight backend as you prototype an app/site or play with a new library. You can even let other people make changes to the data, if you¬†wish.

Alex Zirbel

Satori: Convert HTML and CSS to SVG ‚Äî React and JSX are the preferred route in to this, but it‚Äôll work without¬†those. It powers Vercel's new 'social card' image generation feature.

Vercel

Don‚Äôt DIY Your Notifications: Send SMS, Email, and Push with¬†One¬†Call

Courier.com sponsor

Downshift 7.0: Primitives to Build Accessible React¬†Components ‚Äî You get hooks that provide the stateful logic needed to create autocomplete, combo-box and ‚Äòselect‚Äô dropdown components which you can then lean on for WAI-ARIA compliant¬†goodness.

PayPal

üéâ ¬†Canvas Confetti: An On-Demand Confetti Shower ‚Äî Ready to let off some fireworks in your browser? Do it in style with confetti. Plenty of demos to check out. GitHub¬†repo.

Kiril Vatev

  • NPKILL 0.9
    ‚Ü≥ Lists node_modules directories and lets you clean them up.

  • Wild Wild Path 3.3
    ‚Ü≥ Object property paths with wildcards and regexps.

  • capture-website 3.2
    ‚Ü≥ Capture screenshots of websites with Puppeteer.

  • Mongoose 6.7
    ‚Ü≥ MongoDB object modeling library for Node.js.

üíª Jobs

Become a Senior JS/TS Developer for a Leading Rich Text Editor ‚Äî Take the next step in your career and help us migrate CKEditor 5 to TypeScript. Develop the software used by millions of users¬†üåé
CKEditor

Software Engineer ‚Äî Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're always looking for more exceptional¬†engineers.
Stickermule

Find JavaScript Jobs with Hired ‚Äî Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free for¬†job-seekers.
Hired

Software Engineer (Security) ‚Äî Join our "kick ass" team. Our software team operates from 17 countries and we're looking for more exceptional engineers to join our Security¬†team.
Sticker Mule

üëª And just in time for Halloween..

Creepyface: Makes Images of Faces 'Follow' the Pointer ‚Äî This is an effect we‚Äôve seen mostly on ‚Äòabout us‚Äô pages where faces of team members follow your pointer around. If you want to recreate that, here you go.. and in a timely Halloween edition too. (React user? There's a component for¬†that.)

Alejandro Tard√≠n

items.title: ü™ú Decorating with Dr. Axel
items.content:
#‚Äã611 ‚Äî October 21, 2022

Read on the Web
Together with¬†

JavaScript Weekly

Metaprogramming with the 2022-03 Decorators API ‚Äî If you‚Äôre a Python developer, you‚Äôll be miles ahead on this idea. If not, decorators provide a way to manipulate classes, fields, methods, and accessors at define time to give them extra, amended, or wrapped functionality or behavior. The proposal is at stage 3 at TC39, is supported by Babel, and will soon be supported by TypeScript, so why not get up to speed with Dr. R.

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Node.js 19 (Current) Released ‚Äî We did a big feature in yesterday‚Äôs Node Weekly, but in short, this is the new, edgiest 'Current' non-LTS Node.js release which gains a Nodemon-esque --watch mode, HTTP KeepAlive on by default, stable WebCrypto API, and a bump to V8 10.7. Node 18 goes Active LTS next¬†week.

The Node.js Project

Your Source for Candid Chats on Product, Business & Leadership ‚Äî If you‚Äôre looking for insights on how to get to a successful product launch, why being vulnerable can help make you a better leader, or how to ship software with realistic deadlines, the Postlight Podcast is for¬†you.

The Postlight Podcast sponsor

A Real World React to htmx Migration Story ‚Äî htmx is a library that ‚Äòturbo charges‚Äô HTML by letting you use numerous JS and Web API features via custom HTML attributes. Here a Python-based team shows how it worked better for them than a more common React¬†approach.

David Guillot

p5.js 1.5: Creative JS Coding, Now with Animated GIF Exporting ‚Äî p5 is hard to define ‚Äì it‚Äôs like Processing but for JavaScript, and it lets you create creative, visual experiences in the browser. Examples? Why, of course. v1.5 is a significant release as you can now easily save GIFs of your creations which leads to fantastic tweets like this. Basically if you want to generate cool animated GIFs using JavaScript, this should be your first port of¬†call.

Qianqian Ye and Contributors

IN BRIEF:

  • One of Emotion's contributors kicked off a few lunchtime conversations by explaining why his team is 'breaking up' with CSS-in-JS. As no-one says but me, what's new is old again.

  • Not been keeping an eye on browser devtool developments? Patrick Brosset has a Halloween-themed 'What's New in DevTools'¬†roundup üëª

  • The React world is discussing a proposal to add first class support for promises and async/await in client and server components.

  • Two Storybook (the component dev tool) updates: they're baking in first-class Vite support to v7, and they have a newly designed site (it's here.)

  • üé§ Two developers ‚ñ∂Ô∏è discuss jQuery's relevance and ask 'is it really so¬†bad?'

üìÖ ¬†Live Event: Visual Workflow Automation, Now with Code ‚Äî No more one-off scripts, CRON jobs, or ETL tasks. Reclaim your time and build automation like a¬†developer.

Retool sponsor

RELEASES:

  • Prisma 4.5 ‚Äì Modern ORM for Node & TypeScript.
  • Mocha 10.1 ‚Äì Test framework for Node & browser.
  • SolidJS 1.6.0 ‚Äì VDOM-less reactive frontend UI library.
  • Ember.js 4.8.0
  • supabase-js v2

üìí¬†Articles & Tutorials

Creating a World-Class Code Playground with Sandpack ‚Äî CodeSandbox‚Äôs Sandpack is a toolkit for creating ‚Äòlive code editor‚Äô components. Josh Comeau shows off how to use it to good effect to boost your blog posts, courses, and the¬†like.

Josh W Comeau

Secure JavaScript URL Validation ‚Äî Though conforming to a standard structure, URLs come in all shapes and sizes and you may not want your app to accept URLs that are malformed or otherwise problematic. This post covers some of the considerations¬†involved.

Mannan Tirmizi (Snyk)

'What if the Team Hates My Functional Code?' ‚Äî I think most folks who‚Äôve been bitten by the functional programming bug have eventually run into problems when convincing other developers it‚Äôs the way to go. James provides some soothing¬†perspective.

James Sinclair

Why Does JSON.parse 'Corrupt' Large Numbers? ‚Äî Jump into your JavaScript console of choice and try JSON.parse('{"count": 9123372036854000123}') .. you might not get the result you expect, and Jos set out to figure out why and how to resolve it ‚Äì ‚Äòquite a juicy topic‚Äô, he¬†promises.

Jos de Jong

Tutorial: Add SSO & Access Control to Your Node.js App

Userfront sponsor

‚ñ∂¬†¬†Effortless End-to-End Type-Safety with Phero ‚Äî A ten-minute demonstration of a library providing a type-safe TypeScript-based way to communicate between frontend and backend. GitHub¬†repo.

Jasper Haggenburg

Modern CSS in Angular: Layouts
Emma Twersky

How to Use Google Sheets as a Database from React with Serverless
Paul Scanlon

Building a Chat App with Socket.io and React Native
Nevo David

How to Use storage in Web Extensions
David Walsh

üõ†¬†Code & Tools

route-list: CLI Tool to Display Express/Koa/Hapi/Fastify Routes ‚Äî If you‚Äôve got a Node-based webapp and you want to see all of its endpoints in an elegant way, here‚Äôs an¬†option.

Vladimir Mikulic

TypeRunner: A High-Performance TypeScript Compiler ‚Äî The TypeScript project already has its own compiler (tsc - written in TypeScript itself) but this is an independent C++ (no, not Rust for once!) attempt at making type checking even faster. If you‚Äôre asking ‚Äúwhy‚Äù: they have an answer for¬†that.

Marc J. Schmidt

Strong CAPTCHA: A Secure and Scalable Way to Fight Fraud ‚Äî Learn how to combat CAPTCHA fraud without sacrificing user¬†experience.

Stytch sponsor

Angular Starter: Angular 14 plus Storybook, Transloco, Jest, and More ‚Äî Everything but the kitchen¬†sink?

Wilfried Lucha

  • Peaks.js 2.1
    ‚Ü≥ BBC component for interacting with audio waveforms.

  • Reveal.js 4.4
    ‚Ü≥ Write your presentations in HTML. (Demo.)

  • styled-jsx 5.1
    ‚Ü≥ Full, scoped CSS support for JSX.

  • svg-path-morph
    ‚Ü≥ Interpolate between SVG path variations.

  • lowdb 4.0 ‚Äì Simple local JSON database.

  • twgl.js 5.1 ‚Äì Low-level WebGL helper library.

  • PSD 0.3 ‚Äì Fast Photoshop/PSD file parser.

  • SVGuitar 2.0 ‚Äì Create guitar chord charts.

üíª Jobs

Senior JavaScript/TypeScript Developer (Remote or Warsaw) ‚Äî CKEditor is migrating to TypeScript, will you migrate your talent to the CKEditor team? üß≥ Join us and realize your true¬†potential.
CKEditor

Doppler - A SecretOps Platform Built by Developers for Developers ‚Äî Doppler‚Äôs looking for Sr. Full-Stack Engineers to help shape the future of security devtools. TypeScript, React, Express, and Go, apply¬†here.
Doppler

JavaScript Weekly




  





  
  
Metaprogramming with the 2022-03 Decorators API ‚Äî If you‚Äôre a Python developer, you‚Äôll be miles ahead on this idea. If not, decorators provide a way to manipulate classes, fields, methods, and accessors at define time to give them extra, amended, or wrapped functionality or behavior. The proposal is at stage 3 at TC39, is supported by Babel, and will soon be supported by TypeScript, so why not get up to speed  with Dr. R.
Dr. Axel Rauschmayer 


  
  
Node.js 19 (Current) Released ‚Äî We did a big feature in yesterday‚Äôs Node Weekly, but in short, this is the new, edgiest 'Current' non-LTS Node.js release which gains a Nodemon-esque --watch mode, HTTP KeepAlive on by default, stable WebCrypto API, and a bump to V8 10.7. Node 18 goes Active LTS next¬†week.
The Node.js Project 


  
  
Your Source for Candid Chats on Product, Business & Leadership ‚Äî If you‚Äôre looking for insights on how to get to a successful product launch, why being vulnerable can help make you a better leader, or how to ship software with realistic deadlines, the Postlight Podcast is for¬†you.
The Postlight Podcast sponsor


  
  
A Real World React to htmx Migration Story ‚Äî htmx is a library that ‚Äòturbo charges‚Äô HTML by letting you use numerous JS and Web API features via custom HTML attributes. Here a Python-based team shows how it worked better for them than a more common React¬†approach.
David Guillot 





  





  
  
p5.js 1.5: Creative JS Coding, Now with Animated GIF Exporting ‚Äî p5 is hard to define ‚Äì it‚Äôs like Processing but for JavaScript, and it lets you create creative, visual experiences in the browser. Examples? Why, of course. v1.5 is a significant release as you can now easily save GIFs of your creations which leads to fantastic tweets like this. Basically if you want to generate cool animated GIFs using JavaScript, this should be your first port of¬†call.
Qianqian Ye and Contributors 


IN BRIEF:
One of Emotion's contributors kicked off a few lunchtime conversations by explaining why his team is 'breaking up' with CSS-in-JS. As no-one says but me, what's new is old again.
Not been keeping an eye on browser devtool developments? Patrick Brosset has a Halloween-themed 'What's New in DevTools'¬†roundup üëª
The React world is discussing a proposal to add first class support for promises and async/await in client and server components.
Two Storybook (the component dev tool) updates: they're baking in first-class Vite support to v7, and they have a newly designed site (it's here.)
üé§ Two developers ‚ñ∂Ô∏è discuss jQuery's relevance and ask 'is it really so¬†bad?'

Creating a World-Class Code Playground with Sandpack ‚Äî CodeSandbox‚Äôs Sandpack is a toolkit for creating ‚Äòlive code editor‚Äô components. Josh Comeau shows off how to use it to good effect to boost your blog posts, courses, and the¬†like.
Josh W Comeau 


  
  
Secure JavaScript URL Validation ‚Äî Though conforming to a standard structure, URLs come in all shapes and sizes and you may not want your app to accept URLs that are malformed or otherwise problematic. This post covers some of the considerations¬†involved.
Mannan Tirmizi (Snyk) 


  
  
'What if the Team Hates My Functional Code?' ‚Äî I think most folks who‚Äôve been bitten by the functional programming bug have eventually run into problems when convincing other developers it‚Äôs the way to go. James provides some soothing¬†perspective.
James Sinclair 


  
  
Why Does JSON.parse 'Corrupt' Large Numbers? ‚Äî Jump into your JavaScript console of choice and try JSON.parse('{"count": 9123372036854000123}') .. you might not get the result you expect, and Jos set out to figure out why and how to resolve it ‚Äì ‚Äòquite a juicy topic‚Äô, he¬†promises.
Jos de Jong 


  
  
Tutorial: Add SSO & Access Control to Your Node.js App

Vladimir Mikulic 


  
  
TypeRunner: A High-Performance TypeScript Compiler ‚Äî The TypeScript project already has its own compiler (tsc - written in TypeScript itself) but this is an independent C++ (no, not Rust for once!) attempt at making type checking even faster. If you‚Äôre asking ‚Äúwhy‚Äù: they have an answer for¬†that.
